content.webTitle: Wladimir Klitschko to fight Bryant Jennings in New York in April

fields.headline: Wladimir Klitschko to fight Bryant Jennings in New York in April
fields.bodyText: Wladimir Klitschko will defend the world heavyweight championship against Philadelphia’s Bryant Jennings on 25 April at Madison Square Garden. The fight will mark Klitschko’s first bout on American soil in seven years. Klitschko (63-3, 54 KOs), the lineal champion who holds three of the four major alphabet titles, will be making his 18th defense — second only to Joe Louis (25) and Larry Holmes (20) among heavyweights. Unbeaten since a 2004 loss to Lamon Brewster, Klitschko’s last outing was a fifth-round knockout of mandatory challenger Kubrat Pulev in November. Jennings (19-0, 10 KOs) scaled the heavyweight ladder with a pair of HBO-televised wins against undefeated contenders Artur Szpilka and Mike Perez in 2014. Until August, the 30-year-old balanced his boxing career with a full-time day job as a mechanic in the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia’s facilities department. “This is the moment I have been waiting for,” Jennings said in a statement. “Now it’s time to bring the belts home.” Klitschko currently holds the IBF, WBA and WBO belts. The WBC title — vacated by Vitali Klitschko when he retired in 2013 — now belongs to Deontay Wilder, who outpointed Bermane Stiverne on Saturday in Las Vegas. A Klitschko-Wilder fight to fully unify the heavyweight championship for the first time since Lennox Lewis in 2000 now looms, but the 38-year-old Ukranian will need to get past Jennings first. Long speculated to take place at Brooklyn’s Barclays Center, it was confirmed on Tuesday the fight will take place at Madison Square Garden.
